- http://logs.openstack.org/14676/6/check/gate-swift-python27/918 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/14676/6/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm/15688 : SUCCESS
'}, {'account_id': 2696, 'date': '2012-10-26 18:25:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Thanks!'}, {'account_id': 330, 'date': '2012-10-29 05:15:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

So now, if you have a config file that is malformed, you get a Traceback and an unclean exit from swift-init:


$ swift-init proxy start
WARNING: Unable to increase file descriptor limit.  Running as non-root?
Starting proxy-server...(/etc/swift/proxy-server.conf)
Error trying to load config /etc/swift/proxy-server.conf: File contains no section headers.
file: /etc/swift/proxy-server.conf, line: 1
'[DEFAULT\n'
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/local/bin/swift-proxy-server", line 7, in <module>
    execfile(__file__)
  File "/home/john/swift/bin/swift-proxy-server", line 22, in <module>
    run_wsgi(conf_file, 'proxy-server', default_port=8080, **options)
  File "/home/john/swift/swift/common/wsgi.py", line 114, in run_wsgi
    init_request_processor(conf_file, app_section, *args, **kwargs)
TypeError: 'NoneType' object is not iterable


This happens because the exception handing in init_request_processor() is a straight copy/paste from the original. Therefore the 'return' statement 1) doesn't actaully cause run_wsgi() to exit and 2) returns 'None' which can't be expanded into the tuple (the Traceback above).

I'd suggest re-raising the exception and handling it in run_wsgi() rather than printing the error and returning in init_request_processor().'}, {'account_id': 4108, 'date': '2012-10-29 20:31:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

John, thank you for catching this. 
I think it is important to have a specific printout for the more common config exceptions and not mix them with other exceptions. 

So I suggest catch in request_processor_init and print the config error (as done now), than raise instead of return 

We could catch all request_processor_init exceptions second time in run_wsgi, but this does not seem to add value.'}, {'account_id': 4108, 'date': '2012-10-29 20:54:03.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-10-29 22:08:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Works for me

Build successful

- http://logs.openstack.org/14676/7/check/gate-swift-merge/1069 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/14676/7/check/gate-swift-docs/695 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/14676/7/check/gate-swift-pep8/838 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/14676/7/check/gate-swift-python26/943 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/14676/7/check/gate-swift-python27/945 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/14676/7/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm/15964 : SUCCESS
'}, {'account_id': 330, 'date': '2012-10-30 00:08:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

By reraising the exception (which is more correct), you still haven't replaced the previous exception handling in run_wsgi(). This means that the output and return code of swift-init has changed. While there may be better ways to report errors in swift-init, that should be handled in a separate patch and this patch should not change the interface of existing binaries (or more generally, the interface to run_wsgi()).

Please handle the error in run_wsgi()."}, {'account_id': 4108, 'date': '2012-10-30 13:06:01.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-10-30 13:26:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8: Doesn't seem to work

commit_message:
Separate wsgi init from web-front-end activation

Separate the request processor initialization steps
    Load common settings from conf
    Set the logger
    Load the request processor
from the web front end server application step

On branch bp/wsgi-application-interface-7
   modified:   swift/common/wsgi.py

Implements Blueprint:   wsgi-application-interface

Change-Id: I25fabad8846cd644e4bf1e1bd9c2e568512e12e5

messages:
[{'account_id': 2696, 'date': '2012-10-08 20:30:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I'd like to get some bugfixes related to single-range support merged (https://review.openstack.org/#/c/14011/) before this patch, if that's okay."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-10-08 20:35:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Doesn't seem to work Build failed - http://logs.openstack.org/14180/1/check/gate-swift-merge/880 : SUCCESS - http://logs.openstack.org/14180/1/check/gate-swift-docs/506 : SUCCESS - http://logs.openstack.org/14180/1/check/gate-swift-pep8/649 : FAILURE - http://logs.openstack.org/14180/1/check/gate-swift-python26/755 : FAILURE - http://logs.openstack.org/14180/1/check/gate-swift-python27/756 : FAILURE - http://logs.openstack.org/14180/1/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm/13954 : SUCCESS - http://logs.openstack.org/14180/1/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-cinder/3933 : SUCCESS "}, {'account_id': 2828, 'date': '2012-10-09 01:34:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: It'd be nice if it didn't have to repeat all the range logic from range_for_length. Also it'd be good if the multi-range code could be moved higher up, where it could be re-used by stuff like the segmented object iterable that implement their own app_iter_range."}, {'account_id': 2860, 'date': '2012-10-09 13:20:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Darrell Bishop, Not a problem, I can rebase this change after your get in.'}, {'account_id': 2860, 'date': '2012-10-09 13:21:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Michael Barton, A bit more detail on your suggestions, sounds like a great idea. Thanks.'}, {'account_id': 2696, 'date': '2012-10-09 20:45:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: The bugfix patch I was talking about got merged, so you can rebase now. You should have significant merge conflicts, but as long as the tests don't collide too much, you should have good test coverage, at least for the single-range case."}, {'account_id': 2860, 'date': '2012-10-11 01:10:02.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-10-11 01:38:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Doesn't seem to work Build failed - http://logs.openstack.org/14180/2/check/gate-swift-merge/907 : SUCCESS - http://logs.openstack.org/14180/2/check/gate-swift-docs/533 : SUCCESS - http://logs.openstack.org/14180/2/check/gate-swift-pep8/676 : SUCCESS - http://logs.openstack.org/14180/2/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-cinder/4231 : SUCCESS "}, {'account_id': 2860, 'date': '2012-10-11 02:40:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Work In Progress need to fix test cases.'}, {'account_id': 2860, 'date': '2012-10-11 08:38:35.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-10-11 08:57:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Doesn't seem to work Build failed - http://logs.openstack.org/14180/3/check/gate-swift-merge/908 : SUCCESS - http://logs.openstack.org/14180/3/check/gate-swift-docs/534 : SUCCESS - http://logs.openstack.org/14180/3/check/gate-swift-pep8/677 : FAILURE - http://logs.openstack.org/14180/3/check/gate-swift-python26/783 : SUCCESS - http://logs.openstack.org/14180/3/check/gate-swift-python27/784 : SUCCESS - http://logs.openstack.org/14180/3/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm/14269 : SUCCESS - http://logs.openstack.org/14180/3/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-cinder/4248 : SUCCESS "}, {'account_id': 2860, 'date': '2012-10-11 14:19:51.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-10-11 14:38:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Works for me Build successful - http://logs.openstack.org/14180/4/check/gate-swift-merge/909 : SUCCESS - http://logs.openstack.org/14180/4/check/gate-swift-docs/535 : SUCCESS - http://logs.openstack.org/14180/4/check/gate-swift-pep8/678 : SUCCESS - http://logs.openstack.org/14180/4/check/gate-swift-python26/784 : SUCCESS - http://logs.openstack.org/14180/4/check/gate-swift-python27/785 : SUCCESS - http://logs.openstack.org/14180/4/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm/14274 : SUCCESS - http://logs.openstack.org/14180/4/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-cinder/4253 : SUCCESS '}, {'account_id': 2696, 'date': '2012-10-11 16:41:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: I would prefer that you didn't merge this (3 inline comments) A few inline comments. -1 because this patch regresses (at least) the case of "Range: bytes=-17" with a 10-byte object. The correct behavior (which my previous patch fixed) is to return 206 and all the bytes of the object. I thought this case was covered by regression test(s), but maybe they got removed? $ curl -H 'X-Auth-Token: AUTH_tkb90f69f181634a18a8cea5c06c39811d' -H 'Range: bytes=-17' http://192.168.22.2:8080/v1/AUTH_test/test/10bytes ... < HTTP/1.1 416 Request Range Not Satisfiable < Content-Length: 95 < Content-Type: text/html ...

Request Range Not Satisfiable

The Range requested is not available.

'}, {'account_id': 2696, 'date': '2012-10-11 16:47:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Also, the functional tests don't pass :( testRangedGets"}, {'account_id': 2696, 'date': '2012-10-11 17:02:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: (3 inline comments) Ah, confirmed that a unit test regressed with the patch. See inline comments in test_swob.py.'}, {'account_id': 2860, 'date': '2012-10-11 18:25:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: (1 inline comment) Darrell Bishop, According to the spec here. http://www.w3.org/Protocols/rfc2616/rfc2616-sec14.html#sec14.35.1, the first-byte-pos can not be omitted. so a range like -7 should be considered invalid. Where do you see that range to be valid? thanks.'}, {'account_id': 2860, 'date': '2012-10-11 18:52:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Darrell, you are right, the -7 is a valid range, I will make changes accordingly. Thanks.'}, {'account_id': 2860, 'date': '2012-10-11 19:39:06.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-10-11 20:37:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Works for me Build successful - http://logs.openstack.org/14180/5/check/gate-swift-merge/916 : SUCCESS - http://logs.openstack.org/14180/5/check/gate-swift-docs/542 : SUCCESS - http://logs.openstack.org/14180/5/check/gate-swift-pep8/685 : SUCCESS - http://logs.openstack.org/14180/5/check/gate-swift-python26/791 : SUCCESS - http://logs.openstack.org/14180/5/check/gate-swift-python27/792 : SUCCESS - http://logs.openstack.org/14180/5/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm/14325 : SUCCESS - http://logs.openstack.org/14180/5/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-cinder/4304 : SUCCESS '}, {'account_id': 2696, 'date': '2012-10-11 20:51:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: I would prefer that you didn't merge this (2 inline comments) Looks good with one exception about unit test coverage (see inline comment). Also, a comment's text could use some capitalization at the beginnings of sentences. I haven't tested again, but the multi-range feature only seemed to work if the regions were "in order" (which makes sense, since there's iterators involved and an arbitrary range handler would be more complicated). That's a known limitation, correct? For example, with a 10-byte file containing "0123456789", Range: bytes=0-1,-7 correctly gave me "013456789" (in two chunks). But reversing them did not work: Range: bytes=-7,0-1 gave me "3456789" in one chunk followed by an empty chunk. Overlapping ranges do seem to work (at least this trivial one): Range: bytes=0-5,3-7 gave me "01234534567" (in two chunks)'}, {'account_id': 2860, 'date': '2012-10-11 22:18:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Darrel, looking at the your comments now. The overlap ranges should work as you have found.'}, {'account_id': 2860, 'date': '2012-10-11 23:28:31.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 2860, 'date': '2012-10-11 23:29:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Darrel, changes have been made to address that issue. please also see the reply to your comment'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-10-11 23:47:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Works for me Build successful - http://logs.openstack.org/14180/6/check/gate-swift-merge/921 : SUCCESS - http://logs.openstack.org/14180/6/check/gate-swift-docs/547 : SUCCESS - http://logs.openstack.org/14180/6/check/gate-swift-pep8/690 : SUCCESS - http://logs.openstack.org/14180/6/check/gate-swift-python26/796 : SUCCESS - http://logs.openstack.org/14180/6/check/gate-swift-python27/797 : SUCCESS - http://logs.openstack.org/14180/6/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm/14360 : SUCCESS - http://logs.openstack.org/14180/6/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-cinder/4339 : SUCCESS '}, {'account_id': 2696, 'date': '2012-10-12 00:24:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: I would prefer that you didn't merge this (8 inline comments) There are still a few holes in test coverage (see inline comments). That seems problematic. Maybe the SegmentedIterable should (efficiently) implement app_iter_ranges()? How much testing have you done with segmented objects and multi-range requests? That seems like a good thing to add to the unit and/or functional tests. A few other random suggestions (inline). See tools/test-requires for modules the tests want/require.'}, {'account_id': 2696, 'date': '2012-10-12 21:20:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Re: the comment, "# this could be improved, but we don't actually use it", that comment was true before this patch because SegmentedIterable implements app_iter_range(), and so the branch with that comment was never reached by Swift. However, with this patch, because SegmentedIterable does not implement app_iter_ranges(), a multi-range request for a segmented object WILL hit that branch, and this is new. If you want to get this patch in and then fix that branch's implementation later, I would suggest "lying" and returning a 416 and no body. In other words, single-range requests will work for segmented objects, but multi-range requests will not. I think that's better than having a memory-bloat land mine in the code waiting to be hit.'}, {'account_id': 2696, 'date': '2012-10-12 21:25:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7: I would prefer that you didn't merge this (2 inline comments) Still two test coverage holes remaining. I hope that will be the last one.'}, {'account_id': 2860, 'date': '2012-10-26 20:01:31.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 21.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-10-26 20:45:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 21: Doesn't seem to work Build failed - http://logs.openstack.org/14180/21/check/gate-swift-merge/1049 : SUCCESS - http://logs.openstack.org/14180/21/check/gate-swift-docs/675 : SUCCESS - http://logs.openstack.org/14180/21/check/gate-swift-pep8/818 : SUCCESS - http://logs.openstack.org/14180/21/check/gate-swift-python26/923 : FAILURE - http://logs.openstack.org/14180/21/check/gate-swift-python27/925 : SUCCESS - http://logs.openstack.org/14180/21/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm/15752 : SUCCESS "}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2012-10-26 20:50:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 21: Looks like a legitimate test failure; assertRegexpMatches only exists in Python 2.7. http://docs.python.org/library/unittest.html#unittest.TestCase.assertRegexpMatches'}, {'account_id': 2696, 'date': '2012-10-26 22:56:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 21: Sorry I led you astray with the assertRegexpMatches--I tend to be too 2.7-centric. I guess you'll need to change it to something like self.assertTrue(re.match(, )) *sigh*"}, {'account_id': 2696, 'date': '2012-10-26 23:04:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 21: (4 inline comments) Couple more inline comments--mostly test cleanup I think.'}, {'account_id': 2860, 'date': '2012-10-26 23:23:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 21: (4 inline comments) changes are made in next patch.'}, {'account_id': 2860, 'date': '2012-10-26 23:29:56.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 22.'}, {'account_id': 2696, 'date': '2012-10-26 23:41:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 22: Looks good to me (core reviewer) Looks good!'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-10-26 23:48:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 22: Works for me Build successful - http://logs.openstack.org/14180/22/check/gate-swift-merge/1053 : SUCCESS - http://logs.openstack.org/14180/22/check/gate-swift-docs/679 : SUCCESS - http://logs.openstack.org/14180/22/check/gate-swift-pep8/822 : SUCCESS - http://logs.openstack.org/14180/22/check/gate-swift-python26/927 : SUCCESS - http://logs.openstack.org/14180/22/check/gate-swift-python27/929 : SUCCESS - http://logs.openstack.org/14180/22/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm/15793 : SUCCESS '}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2012-10-27 01:06:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 22: I would prefer that you didn't merge this I poked at it with curl, and I found a few spots where there are small deviations from RFC2616. Issue 1: A GET request with "Range: bytes=-" gets back a 503. Looks like line 509 in swob.py is trying to compute length - end, which winds up being int - NoneType. I see a 500 from the object server in my logs with that in the stack trace. I think the correct response is a 400 in this case. RFC2616 says: "The recipient of a byte-range-set that includes one or more syntactically invalid byte-range-spec values MUST ignore the header field that includes that byte-range-set." However, "bytes=-" doesn't match the grammar given for byte-range-set (section 14.35.1), so I'd argue that this is a case of malformed syntax, and 400 is the right response code. [That is to say, "bytes=-" is not a syntactically invalid byte-range spec, in which case the right response would be a 200. It's not a byte-range-spec at all.] Issue 2: I have a 71-byte object that I'm testing with. A GET request with "Range: bytes=0-9,100-200" gets back a 416. Based on my reading of RFC2616, specifically this part: If a syntactically valid byte-range-set includes at least one byte- range-spec whose first-byte-pos is less than the current length of the entity-body, or at least one suffix-byte-range-spec with a non- zero suffix-length, then the byte-range-set is satisfiable. Otherwise, the byte-range-set is unsatisfiable. If the byte-range-set is unsatisfiable, the server SHOULD return a response with a status of 416 (Requested range not satisfiable). Otherwise, the server SHOULD return a response with a status of 206 (Partial Content) containing the satisfiable ranges of the entity-body. it seems that the response should be a 206 and give me back bytes 0-9. Issue 3: Again, I'm using a 71-byte object. A GET request with "Range: bytes=65-75" correctly returns to me bytes 65-71. However, the Content-Range header has value "bytes=65-75". Since only bytes 65-71 are included, it should say "bytes=65-71". Issue 4: Same 71-byte object, GET w/"Range: bytes=0-9,65-75". The Content-Range entity headers on each chunk are correct, but the Content-Range header has value "bytes=0-9,65-75". Based on RFC2616 section 10.2.7, I think a multipart response shouldn't have a Content-Range header at all. Issue 5: Same 71-byte object, GET w/"Range: bytes=0-9". The Content-Range header is "bytes=0-9". Based on the grammar in section 14.16, I think it should be "bytes 0-9". (I'm looking where it says byte-content-range-spec = bytes-unit SP ...) I haven't had a chance to do a proper line-by-line code review yet; I hope to have time for that soon. However, it looks like Darrell's been quite thorough here, so I don't expect to find much when I do mine.'}, {'account_id': 2696, 'date': '2012-10-27 04:31:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 22: @Sam: Issue 3: Shouldn't the Content-Range header also have a trailing "/#" where # is the full entity body length? cf. http://www.w3.org/Protocols/rfc2616/rfc2616-sec14.html#sec14.16 Using your example, I would expect: Content-Range: bytes 65-71/75 Note the space between "bytes" and "65". Issue 5: Same comment as above regarding the format specified for Content-Range in section 14.16.'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2012-10-27 04:39:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 22: @Darrell: you are absolutely correct; there should be a trailing / in both those cases.'}, {'account_id': 2860, 'date': '2012-10-27 15:29:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 22: Sam, for issue 1, rfc2616 defines the Range as follows: Range = "Range" ":" ranges-specifier ranges-specifier = byte-ranges-specifier byte-ranges-specifier = bytes-unit "=" byte-range-set byte-range-set = 1#( byte-range-spec | suffix- byte-range-spec ) byte-range-spec = first-byte-pos "-" [last-byte-pos] first-byte-pos = 1*DIGIT last-byte-pos = 1*DIGIT suffix-byte-range-spec = "-" suffix-length suffix-length = 1*DIGIT According to this definition, I do not think Range:bytes=- can be considered syntactically valid since it is missing the first-byte-pos and it does not have suffix-length to be considered as suffix-byte-range-spec. so if that is the Range header, by ignore this header, the response will contain the entire object. This is an easy case, think about this Range:bytes=-,-,-,-, no valid range so the header gets ignored, the response should look just like the first case. one more case like this Range: bytes=-,2-5,-, there is at least one valid range, so the response will contain one range, no section headers. Now the last case, like this Range: bytes=-,2-5, 6-3, 8-10, there are two valid ranges, it should have two sections in the response body, with no content-range header in the response, but content-range in each section. this long comment is to make sure that everybody on the same page of understanding this spec. least one valid range,'}, {'account_id': 2860, 'date': '2012-10-27 19:37:09.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 23.'}, {'account_id': 2860, 'date': '2012-10-27 19:40:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 22: Sam, All your discussed issues are covered in patch 23. please run your test again and see if the results match what you expected.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-10-27 20:33:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 23: Doesn't seem to work Build failed - http://logs.openstack.org/14180/23/check/gate-swift-merge/1055 : SUCCESS - http://logs.openstack.org/14180/23/check/gate-swift-docs/681 : SUCCESS - http://logs.openstack.org/14180/23/check/gate-swift-pep8/824 : SUCCESS - http://logs.openstack.org/14180/23/check/gate-swift-python26/929 : SUCCESS - http://logs.openstack.org/14180/23/check/gate-swift-python27/931 : SUCCESS - http://logs.openstack.org/14180/23/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm/15810 : FAILURE "}, {'account_id': 2696, 'date': '2012-10-27 22:42:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 23: @Tong: re Issue 1, 14.35.1 says, "The recipient of a byte-range-set that includes one or more syntactically invalid byte-range-spec values MUST ignore the header field that includes that byte-range-set." So it's not "at least one" valid range to get a 206, it's "any invalid range" results in an ignored Range header and a 200 with full body. I believe Sam was making a distinction between Range: bytes=10-5 which matches the syntax of the RFC, but which is specifically called out as being "syntactically invalid" and this Range: bytes=- which could be considered to not even *have* a byte-range-spec because the syntax defines a byte-range-spec as starting with a number, then a dash, then optionally another number. In other words, Range: bytes=- is so far from being possibly correct that it warrants a 400 response.'}, {'account_id': 2860, 'date': '2012-10-28 03:28:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 23: Darrell, yes, if there is one invalid, 200 is returned. I've made that change in patch 23."}, {'account_id': 2860, 'date': '2012-10-28 03:28:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 23: recheck'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-10-28 03:42:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 23: Works for me Build successful - http://logs.openstack.org/14180/23/check/gate-swift-merge/1056 : SUCCESS - http://logs.openstack.org/14180/23/check/gate-swift-docs/682 : SUCCESS - http://logs.openstack.org/14180/23/check/gate-swift-pep8/825 : SUCCESS - http://logs.openstack.org/14180/23/check/gate-swift-python26/930 : SUCCESS - http://logs.openstack.org/14180/23/check/gate-swift-python27/932 : SUCCESS - http://logs.openstack.org/14180/23/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm/15833 : SUCCESS '}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2012-10-28 05:12:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 23: I would prefer that you didn't merge this 1) I still think there should be a 400 returned for bogus Range headers. Consider "Range: bytes=bert-ernie"; that'll currently get you a 200, even though that's not a string that the byte-ranges-specifier grammar will produce. Likewise, the following Range headers will cause a 200 to be returned, even though none of them are strings that can be produced from the byte-ranges-specifier grammar. (The grammar's at line 7700 in the text version of RFC2616; section 14.35.1.) - Range: characters=0-10 - Range: Kenmore - Range: bytes=- - Range: bytes= I think the parsing of the Range header has to be stricter, and anything that doesn't fit the grammar has to result in a 400. 2) A truncated byte range still comes back with an incorrect Content-Range header. For a 71-byte object and "Range: bytes=65-75", the response header should be: Content-Range: bytes 65-70/71 Instead, this is the header: Content-Range: bytes=65-75. What's interesting is that the *entity* headers on a multipart response are correct, so there's already code in this diff that's doing the right thing. It's only the *response* header in the single-range case that's busted.'}, {'account_id': 2860, 'date': '2012-10-28 18:44:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 23: Sam, that is right, the single range behaves like one entire object retrieval. that is, there is no section header, the response body is the content for that range. Only when two or more ranges returned, there will be section headers. The content-range header is also removed from the the headers but exists in the section header. The value should be correct. for single range, the behavior is exactly same as before. The content-range for the response is copied from the request. That is how it behaved before this multi range support was added. I think it can be re-worked on. but there are also issues like this, in the request header, the range might look like this: Range:bytes=5-, 20-30, -30 they are all valid, but in the content-range, they may look a little different, for example, they will be transformed into content-range: byte 5-400/401, 20-30/401, 371-400/401 Notice for given size of 401 content, the content range returned is accurate but in a different form. regarding the 400 response for invalid range body, I think they should be ignored just like other syntactically invalid ranges, should return 200, rather than 200.'}, {'account_id': 2860, 'date': '2012-10-29 19:11:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 23: Behaviors from nginx: 1. bytes=- => 416 Content-Range: bytes */1392 2. bytes=-0 => 416 Content-Range: bytes */1392 3. bytes=5-3 => 416 Content-Range: bytes */1392 4. bytes=3-5,5-3 => 206 Content-Range: bytes 3-5/1392 5. bytes=5-3,3-5 => 206 Content-Range: bytes 3-5/1392 6. bytes=3-5,6-9 => 206 no content-range only section content-range 7. bytes=3-5,6-9,- => 416 Content-Range: bytes */1392 8. bytes=3-5,6-9,-0 => 206 two sections, no content-range only section content-range 9. bytes=3-5,6-9,-10 => 206 three sections, no content-range only section content-range 10.bytes=foobar,3-5 => 416 Content-Range: bytes */1392 11.bytes=3-5,foobar => 416 Content-Range: bytes */1392 12.bytes=0-0 => 206 Content-Range: bytes 0-0/1392 13.bytes=0-0,13-10 => 206 Content-Range: bytes 0-0/1392 14.nobytes=3-5,6-9 => 200 No content range header Behaviros from apache2 1. bytes=- => 200 No Content-Range header 2. bytes=-0 => 200 No Content-Range header 3. bytes=5-3 => 200 No Content-Range header 4. bytes=3-5,5-3 => 200 No Content-Range header 5. bytes=5-3,3-5 => 200 No Content-Range header 6. bytes=3-5,6-9 => 206 No content-range only section content-range 7. bytes=3-5,6-9,- => 200 No Content-Range header 8. bytes=3-5,6-9,-0 => 200 No Content-Range header 9. bytes=3-5,6-9,-10 => 206 three sections, no content-range only section content-range 10.bytes=foobar,3-5 => 200 No Content-Range header 11.bytes=3-5,foobar => 200 No Content-Range header 12.bytes=0-0 => 206 Content-Range: bytes 0-0/177 13.bytes=0-0,13-10 => 200 No Content-Range header 14.nobytes=3-5,6-9 => 200 No content range header'}, {'account_id': 2860, 'date': '2012-10-29 19:13:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 23: Sam, Darrell, please see the behaviors recorded from both nginx and apache2. seems to me that apache2 is more closer to the spec other than the Range:bytes=-0 case. I think that we probably should just follow apache2 behaviors for our implementation.'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2012-10-30 00:34:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 23: You're pitting my pedantry against my pragmatism. My head may explode. :) I still think it's wrong to return anything but a 400 in those error cases. However, I'll grudgingly accept Apache's behavior. It feels more internally consistent than nginx's behavior, and if the 2 most popular HTTP servers get it wrong, then it's not the end of the world if we join them. So, in that case, the only remaining bug I see is in the Content-Range header for single-range requests. I guess the code to do that was broken before this diff (swift/common/swob.py:876 with patchset 23 applied). I'd like that to be fixed with this diff, but if you strongly disagree, then I can probably be persuaded to put that off to a separate change."}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2012-10-30 01:16:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 23: (7 inline comments) A couple inline comments.'}, {'account_id': 2860, 'date': '2012-10-30 13:31:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 23: Sam, I've talked to Darrell yesterday, for the single range request, the content-range in response will be reworked in next patch(patches), I still do not see an end to this patch (yet). So not a problem, since we are at this, need to make it right."}, {'account_id': 2860, 'date': '2012-10-30 13:40:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 23: (7 inline comments) Sam, please see the inline responses. new patch will come soon, thanks for reviewing this.'}, {'account_id': 2696, 'date': '2012-10-30 15:21:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 23: (1 inline comment) Suggestion for the confusing "comment" (which was actually a multi-line string, I guess).'}, {'account_id': 2696, 'date': '2012-10-30 16:39:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 23: Can you add "DocImpact" to your commit message? I've got a 71-byte object, and "Range: bytes=0-10,20-30" gets me a 416, even though "Range: bytes=0-10" and "Range: bytes=20-30" both work correctly with a 206. Also, there are functional test failures.'}, {'account_id': 2696, 'date': '2012-10-31 18:17:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 26: I would prefer that you didn't merge this (4 inline comments) Inline comments; most important are the ones about unsatisfiable ranges vs. syntactically-invalid ranges. Also, the response for the case Range: bytes=-0 is also incorrectly returning 200 instead of 416. That is clearly syntactically valid in the grammar, and the RFC says If a syntactically valid byte-range-set includes... at least one suffix-byte-range-spec with a non-zero suffix-length, then the byte-range-set is satisfiable. Otherwise, the byte-range-set is unsatisfiable. If the byte-range-set is unsatisfiable, the server SHOULD return a response with a status of 416 (Requested range not satisfiable)."}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2012-10-31 21:14:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 26: Here's a list of tests that I'm going to perform (with curl) when testing this patch: http://paste.openstack.org/show/23310/ I hope it helps."}, {'account_id': 2860, 'date': '2012-11-01 00:06:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 26: (4 inline comments) see new patch and the inline response.'}, {'account_id': 2860, 'date': '2012-11-01 00:18:47.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 27.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-11-01 00:33:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 27: Works for me Build successful - revisions:
[{'created': '2012-10-08 20:04:16.000000000', 'message': 'blueprint Multi-range support implementation

this change added multi-range support to OpenStack Swift. With
this implementation, a openstack client can use Range header
to specify multipal ranges to indicate the requested content.

The blueprint can be found here
https://blueprints.launchpad.net/swift/+spec/multi-range-support

Change-Id: I4ed1fb0a0a93c037ddb2f551ea62afe447945107
'}, {'created': '2012-10-11 01:10:02.000000000', 'message': 'blueprint Multi-range support implementation

this change added multi-range support to OpenStack Swift. With
this implementation, a openstack client can use Range header
to specify multipal ranges to indicate the requested content.

Change-Id: I4ed1fb0a0a93c037ddb2f551ea62afe447945107
'}, {'created': '2012-10-11 08:38:35.000000000', 'message': 'blueprint Multi-range support implementation

commit_message:
blueprint Multi-range support implementation

This change adds multi range retrieval to OpenStack Swift. For non-
segmented data object, a client can use HTTP Range header to specify
multiple ranges to retrieve sections of the data object.

This implementation currently does not support segmented data object
multi range retrieval. When a client sends a multi range request
against a segmented data object, Swift will return HTTP status code
200. Support for segmented data multi range retrieval will be added
in near future.

This implementation is to bring Swift closer to CDMI multi range
data retrieval standard. Once support for segemented data multi
range is added, Swift will be compliant with CDMI standard in
this area.

DocImpact

Change-Id: I4ed1fb0a0a93c037ddb2f551ea62afe447945107

[{'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-10-31 01:20:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Doesn't seem to work

Build failed

- http://logs.openstack.org/15084/1/check/gate-nova-merge/10852 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/15084/1/check/gate-nova-docs/6603 : SUCCESS

- http://logs.openstack.org/15084/1/check/gate-nova-python26/8056 : FAILURE
- http://logs.openstack.org/15084/1/check/gate-nova-python27/8123 : FAILURE
- http://logs.openstack.org/15084/1/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm/16173 : FAILURE
- http://logs.openstack.org/15084/1/check/gate-nova-pylint/2143 : FAILURE (non-voting)
"}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2012-10-31 05:59:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I'd like to offer an alternative solution that requires much less changes to the compute manager.  Ideally it'd be nice to pass in the ComputeManager to the compute driver on initialization.  If drivers stored this, they could then just call something like self.manager.instance_update().  We can expose some other db calls this way as well without having to pass callbacks for every single one into the drivers."}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2012-10-31 13:37:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I thought about doing it that way, but I think I'd prefer an object of operations instead of passing the entire manager through. With the latter approach, I think we further blur the line between the manager and the driver, in terms of what the driver is allowed to do with the database (and anything else the manager has control over). What do you think of that?

However, the reason I went with the fine-grained callback approach is: We're trying to move database accesses out (as far as possible) out of the compute service entirely. If we just hand them a service object (or the manager itself) at init, then we don't end up pushing anything up a layer, and the visibility into where the accesses are happening is a little less clear. By taking the approach in this patch, I moved some query-type accesses up into the manager, and clearly defined which driver operations do instance updates."}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2012-10-31 15:19:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Rebased'}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2012-10-31 15:20:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Automatically re-added by Gerrit trivial rebase detection script."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-10-31 15:49:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

'}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2012-10-31 16:15:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Right... how about handing a new object that defines specific methods instead of the full manager class?

There might be value in identifying which driver methods are making DB updates right now, but I'm afraid of making assumptions that would limit a future driver.  I prefer handing a driver a set of interfaces, saying "Here, Mr. Driver: these are the things you may call".  If drivers need to make different calls in the future, we won't have to worry about changing the driver method signatures.'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2012-10-31 20:27:36.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-10-31 20:48:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Doesn't seem to work

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-10-31 01:06:22.000000000', 'message': "Remove all db.instance_update() from nova/virt

This builds upon the previous patches to completely remove
the use of db.instance_update() from everything in nova/virt.
The compute manager passes in an update callback to the
relevant operations, which provides us the indirection needed
later to move database updates even further away from
nova-compute.

There are still some database operations remaining in the
virt drivers, but the majority are (were) instance update
operations, which this patch removes. The libvirt driver
is (after this patch) completely devoid of standalone
database accesses, as are powervm and baremetal.

XenAPI, you're next.

Related to bp/no-db-compute

Change-Id: I2e40831f5cfb20a03b304097d84d592aab035ef1

commit_message:
Introduce VirtAPI to nova/virt

This patch introduces a VirtAPI class which will house
callbacks provided by the manager to the virt drivers, allowing
things such as direct database accesses to be pulled out of
the virt drivers and delegated to another service.

As a first step, this introduces an instance_update() method
and makes all the virt drivers use it instead of direct calls
to db.instance_update.*().

Change-Id: I2e40831f5cfb20a03b304097d84d592aab035ef1

subject: Add new cpu_util meter recording CPU utilization %.
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3, 'name': 'Jenkins', 'username': 'jenkins'}, {'_account_id': 595, 'name': 'Nick Barcet', 'email': 'nicolas@barcet.com', 'username': 'nijaba'}, {'_account_id': 1669, 'name': 'Julien Danjou', 'display_name': 'jd', 'email': 'julien@danjou.info', 'username': 'jdanjou'}, {'_account_id': 2284, 'name': 'Eoghan Glynn', 'email': 'eglynn@redhat.com', 'username': 'eglynn'}, {'_account_id': 2472, 'name': 'Doug Hellmann', 'email': 'dhellmann@redhat.com', 'username': 'doug-hellmann'}, {'_account_id': 4277, 'name': 'John Tran', 'email': 'jhtran@att.com', 'username': 'jtran'}, {'_account_id': 5679, 'name': 'Yaniv Kaul', 'email': 'ykaul@redhat.com', 'username': 'ykaul'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-11-02 15:24:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

Build successful

- http://logs.openstack.org/14921/2/check/gate-ceilometer-merge/571 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/14921/2/check/gate-ceilometer-pep8/568 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/14921/2/check/gate-ceilometer-python26/568 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/14921/2/check/gate-ceilometer-python27/570 : SUCCESS
'}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-11-02 15:24:18.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-11-02 15:24:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Works for me

Build successful

- http://logs.openstack.org/14921/3/check/gate-ceilometer-merge/572 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/14921/3/check/gate-ceilometer-pep8/569 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/14921/3/check/gate-ceilometer-python26/569 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/14921/3/check/gate-ceilometer-python27/571 : SUCCESS
'}, {'account_id': 1669, 'date': '2012-11-02 15:24:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

@Doug I understand that this may be needed for capacity planning, but wouldn't that be more smart to compute it via the API rather than storing it twice in the db?"}, {'account_id': 1669, 'date': '2012-11-02 15:24:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

I'm ok to merge this as long as this is really needed by someone and that there's a comment with a FIXME above stating that should be moved elsewhere.

If it can wait, I'd prefer to have this handled by the CW publisher and the API."}, {'account_id': 1669, 'date': '2012-11-02 15:24:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I'm having a hard time about this. I really don't like the idea to compute stuff and build new counters based on this.

To me, this is something that should be provided by the API, otherwise we're going to meter and *store* dozens of different version of the same source value. I'd be happier if we'd store one format and compute the other through the API."}, {'account_id': 1669, 'date': '2012-11-02 15:24:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

I agree with the secondary publisher approach rather than a second metric. That'd mean your publisher would convert what the pollster gets to what it needs (i.e. %)

For the total number of cores, if this is needed I think the best way is to add this in the metadata fields on the current counter. :)"}, {'account_id': 1669, 'date': '2012-11-02 15:24:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

No, unless I miss something, I don't think that his interest Ceilometer users at all as it is. Only CW users, that's why it should be a problem in the CW publisher, not in the pollster."}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-11-02 15:24:18.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-11-02 15:24:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

@jd_

OK, so the application I had in mind was publishing the CPU utilization % to CloudWatch (in addition to the celio metering store).

In this case, for reasons of timeliness IMO it would make much more sense to drive the CW PutMetricData call directly from a publisher associated with the libvirt pollster, as opposed to deriving it as a secondary metric from data already stored in the ceilometer metering store.

Also in order to estimate the CPU util for a guest, we'd need to start storing additional info in the metering store, specifically the total number of cores on the host (in addition to the number of core associated with the guest).

Does that reasoning change your disposition to this patch any?

Cheers,
Eoghan"}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-11-02 15:24:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

@jd_

So if the CPU utilization metric was *only* of interest to CloudWatch, then I guess doing the CPU time->util % conversion in the relevant CW Transformer would be reasonable.

However, in this case, IIUC this measure is of interest both to pure ceilometer users and to a future CW consumer. 

In cases where more than one publisher has interest in a measure, it seems to make most sense to compute it once and once only.

In the case of CW, that one place should be as close as possible to the source of the measure, for reasons of timeliness.

Which all seems to point to the pollster as the most reasonable location for this calculation.

Cheers,
Eoghan'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-11-02 15:24:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Works for me

Build successful

- http://logs.openstack.org/14921/4/check/gate-ceilometer-merge/602 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/14921/4/check/gate-ceilometer-pep8/599 : SUCCESS

This, however, reinforces the need to be able to set which counters we care about in a given deployment on an individual basis.'}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-11-02 15:24:18.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2012-11-02 15:24:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Our product manager is interesting in seeing these values for capacity planning during our beta. We could use a custom pollster to collect them, but it seems like they might be useful to other people, too (for the same reason, outside of CW triggers). We've also discussed collecting % utilization of the hypervisor host to be used in the nova scheduler. That's similar data in yet another form.

I'm not sure if any of that helps with the decision of whether to include the new meter or not. Maybe we need to have a discussion about what to do with these "redundant" measures?'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2012-11-02 15:24:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: (3 inline comments)

'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2012-11-02 15:24:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Regarding whether to compute this from the  agent or from the API, I'm really not sure. I assume with the efforts to merge similar stats from heat we may have other counters we want to publish but not store. Do we wait to create those until we have a way to configure where the data should be sent? Either way makes sense to me."}, {'account_id': 4277, 'date': '2012-11-02 15:24:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

commit_message:
Add new cpu_util meter recording CPU utilization %.

The existing cpu meter records cumlative time, which is not
the most useful measure in all cases.

We now also estimate the CPU utilization % based on sampling
the time over subsequent polling cycles, and correcting for the
fraction of host cores available to the instance. The usefulness
of the util estimate depends in part on the polling period,
which is assumed will be short (of the order of 1s) when this
measurement is used in anger (for example to drive alarming).

Change-Id: Icd7de1b2cbce12396a82a3f34acb6c39c1120992

[{'created': '2012-11-01 22:04:15.000000000', 'message': 'Fix glance-api exception when using copy_from with glance CLI

In Folsom a few classes got refactored and during the
process a couple of methods got _lost_. As far as
I can tell the classes in question are:

- CooperativeReader
- ResponseIndexable

These small additions solve bug 1057322

Change-Id: Ib371cb7b065c1952fc9247adf47084bc917a8e69
'}]
commit_message:
Fix glance-api exception when using copy_from with glance CLI

In Folsom a few classes got refactored and during the
process a couple of methods got _lost_. As far as
I can tell the classes in question are:

- CooperativeReader
- ResponseIndexable

These small additions solve bug 1057322

Change-Id: Ib371cb7b065c1952fc9247adf47084bc917a8e69

commit_message:
Add newline between rows of Admin usage.csv

For some reason, we must also specify precision for vcpu hours
in this change. Adding the newline caused the default behavior
to change.

Fix bug 1073677

Change-Id: Id9a90e787de50f775ed17b15f185273cebba64e8

Updated cfntools require authentication for cfn-push-stats,
so the AutoScaling template needs the user/key and boto.cfg
additions, same as in the HA templates, otherwise cfn-push-stats,
and hence autoscaling doesn't work

Change-Id: Ib3ef4a932bb656f29e25ef745409f5fe3e82c356
Signed-off-by: Steven Hardy <shardy@redhat.com>
"}]
commit_message:
heat templates : Align AutoScaling template with cfntools

Updated cfntools require authentication for cfn-push-stats,
so the AutoScaling template needs the user/key and boto.cfg
additions, same as in the HA templates, otherwise cfn-push-stats,
and hence autoscaling doesn't work

Change-Id: Ib3ef4a932bb656f29e25ef745409f5fe3e82c356
Signed-off-by: Steven Hardy <shardy@redhat.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-11-01 07:46:51.000000000', 'message': 'Improve EC2 describe_security_groups performance

The current implementation of EC2 describe_security_groups makes one
query per grantee group rule in _format_security_group. This will
dramatically slow down response time if users make strong use of
grantee group rules.

This patch uses just one DB query to get security groups with joined
grantee_group rules to improve the performance.

Fixes bug 1073024.

Change-Id: I34f3253bfef0eabfea39819de03a274dd6f6aaa8
'}]
commit_message:
Improve EC2 describe_security_groups performance

The current implementation of EC2 describe_security_groups makes one
query per grantee group rule in _format_security_group. This will
dramatically slow down response time if users make strong use of
grantee group rules.

This patch uses just one DB query to get security groups with joined
grantee_group rules to improve the performance.

Fixes bug 1073024.

Change-Id: I34f3253bfef0eabfea39819de03a274dd6f6aaa8

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-11-01 20:29:32.000000000', 'message': 'Bump the base rpc version of the network api.

In d96102b we bumped the RPC version of the migrate_instance_*
calls in the network rpcapi. We did not however bump the associated
RPC version in the network manager and as such resizes are now
broken.

This commit simply bumps the RPC version of the network
manager based on the previous change.

Fixes LP Bug #1074072.

Change-Id: I4b6d6bdbcb7bb68872deee4f54b1c0636012c2cf
'}]
commit_message:
Bump the base rpc version of the network api.

In d96102b we bumped the RPC version of the migrate_instance_*
calls in the network rpcapi. We did not however bump the associated
RPC version in the network manager and as such resizes are now
broken.

This commit simply bumps the RPC version of the network
manager based on the previous change.

Fixes LP Bug #1074072.

Change-Id: I4b6d6bdbcb7bb68872deee4f54b1c0636012c2cf

I guess I have two concerns with the move:

1) it is possible we are depending on something in the network update code that has been changed in the interim.

2) we are changing the logic in a failure scenario. Before if the floating ip update failed we would throw an exception before the intervening code executed. Now we can get all the way through an instance update and then fail to move an ip at the end. I'm not sure which is "better", I just would worry that this will cause unexpected changes.'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-10-29 23:21:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

commit_message:
Add rxtx_factor to network migration logic

Currently, when an instance is migrated from one host to another, the
only action the network API is able to take is moving floating IP
addresses.  We also need to be able to update the rxtx_factor value
to update QoS settings.  This change makes sure that the network APIs
will be passed the rxtx_factor value during a migration.

Change-Id: If4e1e96b84ee082c2d277c3d91da7df0325fc1ff

commit_message:
Decouple sql debug and support echo='debug'

Use sql_debug instead of debug to control sql
debugging. Support echo='debug' on create_engine using a new
sql_verbose. Use default for echo rather than echo='false' as
this works consistently on multiple versions of sqlalchemy

Fixes bug 1041308
Change-Id: I3c9403bc4be408295fc8bd7e6ff2c526a8e8bcdc

commit_message:
Use mock dbapi to tolerate mysql restart

Use the create_engine module=dbapi parameter to
override engine behaviour and therefore
wrap a retry around mysql queries.  This tolerates
mysql restarts when sql_max_retries is set

Fixes bug 1040694

Change-Id: I80d4f054667f78b52cb3dcf045c4e08ba76db387

commit_message:
Handle down object servers in container-sync

If an object server is down, container-sync stops syncing the container
even if the it gets object copies from "up" obejct servers.

Bug 1069910

In case the git history gets mangled, this fix was done almost entirely
by Donagh McCabe <donagh.mccabe@hp.com>.

Change-Id: Ieeadcfeb4e880fe5f08e284d7c12492bf7a29460

Fixes publishing call in compute/central agents.

Fixes bug 1073482.

Modifies the compute-agent and central-agent to correctly call the
new publishing api and modifies the test case accordingly.

commit_message:
Remove nova-volume scheduling support

Continuation of I0b540e54dbabd26901a7530035a38583bb521fda

* delete scheduler.simple
* modify scheduler.multi instead of delete to continue supporting
  I753e87fc8979fd0b62529974f00cf11fa55b3d63
* update scheduler.multi docstring
* scheduler.rpcapi bumped to 2.3
* change default scheduler to scheduler.filter_scheduler

DocImpact

part of bp delete-nova-volume

Change-Id: Ie9d9b46742b2d92cd1e9ffe982ef658907a1d411

on the road to making devstack support multiple databases extract
mysql's configuration like openstack core components are extracted
to make it much easier to replicate this with another database like
postgresql.

This does not address all the places where quantum directly touches

Part of blueprint:postgresql-support

Change-Id: Ie6bea95abefd0836fd020ec0b78fe36b8628d69a
"}]
commit_message:
refactor out mysql configuration

on the road to making devstack support multiple databases extract
mysql's configuration like openstack core components are extracted
to make it much easier to replicate this with another database like
postgresql.

This does not address all the places where quantum directly touches
mysql because that work is still in flux.

Part of blueprint:postgresql-support

Change-Id: Ie6bea95abefd0836fd020ec0b78fe36b8628d69a

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-11-01 18:53:48.000000000', 'message': 'Fix backwards compat of rpc to compute manager

Commit dcabd6159abcdccd99e55495ec005926465007a8 changed compute
manager in a way that it will fail to respond to the older 2.X rpc
message for reserve_block_device_name. This fixes it by making
the volume_id parameter optional.

Change-Id: Ia2d353d5b195e5687917ef5f928c0c835ffe3d3a
'}]
commit_message:
Fix backwards compat of rpc to compute manager

Commit dcabd6159abcdccd99e55495ec005926465007a8 changed compute
manager in a way that it will fail to respond to the older 2.X rpc
message for reserve_block_device_name. This fixes it by making
the volume_id parameter optional.

Change-Id: Ia2d353d5b195e5687917ef5f928c0c835ffe3d3a

bug 1054168 - documents v1 and v2 Image API details

Change-Id: I1e678ae98448928ca5096da5fdc01a5bb9c8bddf

bug 1054168 - documents v1 and v2 Image API details
bug 1073003 - debian listed twice
bug 1073005 - NTP best practices
bug 1073370 - mismatch in sept/oct Folsom date listings
bug 1068971 - adds PostgreSQL description for nova database, rather than keystone
thinking of rewriting entire database into one section anyway... so this may be
a poor fix to the bug but would like input.

Rebase against master.

Change-Id: I1e678ae98448928ca5096da5fdc01a5bb9c8bddf

commit_message:
Fix doc bugs in Install guide

bug 1054168 - documents v1 and v2 Image API details
bug 1073003 - debian listed twice
bug 1073005 - NTP best practices
bug 1073370 - mismatch in sept/oct Folsom date listings
bug 1068971 - adds PostgreSQL description for nova database, rather than keystone
thinking of rewriting entire database into one section anyway... so this may be
a poor fix to the bug but would like input.

Rebase against master.

Change-Id: I1e678ae98448928ca5096da5fdc01a5bb9c8bddf

I am going to put a hold on this review until I get some feedback from some security folks.  I think it is fine as is, but since it has the potential to be an issue down the road, I would rather confirm that the REMOTE_USER env var is secure ahead of time than deal with it if there is a problem after it has been deployed."}, {'account_id': 2218, 'date': '2012-10-26 00:11:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-10-26 00:11:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Doesn't seem to work

This change was unable to be automatically merged with the current state of the repository. Please rebase your change and upload a new patchset."}, {'account_id': 91, 'date': '2012-10-26 07:51:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I'd rather put this configurable and disabled by default."}, {'account_id': 91, 'date': '2012-10-26 09:50:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Nevermind, I overlooked Adams' comments on mailing list."}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2012-10-26 13:20:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Alright, I've been chewing this over, and I really think this would be better implemented as it's own middleware. (e.g. keystone.contrib.middleware.remote_user).

Advantages as middleware:

1) Inherently optional (deployers can exclude it from the pipeline if it's not relevant)... which is obviously a concern for a few people, even if it proves to be unfounded

2) Easier to test in isolation

3) keystone.service continues to expect API spec-compliant requests, and can validate them as such

I'd be happy to help make the transition to middleware, if you need any."}, {'account_id': 2218, 'date': '2012-10-26 13:22:26.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-10-26 13:41:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Works for me

commit_message:
Implements REMOTE_USER authentication support.

Adds support for non-identity authentication via REMOTE_USER environ
context variable thereby permitting external services (paste pipeline,
web fronting or other) to authenticate a request.

Also fixes a pep8 issue.

This change is in support for blueprint
pluggable-identity-authentication-handlers

Change-Id: Ib0a36b14f135dd87601e3c6d28f7874193d66b34

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-10-25 21:59:34.000000000', 'message': 'bug 1068674

Redo part of bp/sql-identiy-pam that was accidently undone by bug 968519.

We encapsulated the call to utils.check_password with a local method,
_check_password, to make it easier to subclass Identity. This allows us
to use a different password checker without having to replace the entire
authenticate method in our code.  The fix for 968519 accidently removed
the call to the local method. *This* fix puts that call back in.

Updating comment because Jenkins failed due to build timeout in
unrelated test.

(cherry picked from commit 0dc2e9ca37497597aa49439e3d3e71c22f30b515)

Change-Id: I69a3ba2d5a62e4c600edab7ef2cc07413c7360cc
'}]
commit_message:
bug 1068674

Redo part of bp/sql-identiy-pam that was accidently undone by bug 968519.

We encapsulated the call to utils.check_password with a local method,
_check_password, to make it easier to subclass Identity. This allows us
to use a different password checker without having to replace the entire
authenticate method in our code.  The fix for 968519 accidently removed
the call to the local method. *This* fix puts that call back in.

Updating comment because Jenkins failed due to build timeout in
unrelated test.

(cherry picked from commit 0dc2e9ca37497597aa49439e3d3e71c22f30b515)

Change-Id: I69a3ba2d5a62e4c600edab7ef2cc07413c7360cc

"}, {'created': '2012-11-01 16:34:26.000000000', 'message': "Remove extra-specs from types-list command output

type-list was including the extra-specs info in it's response,
however extra-specs are admin accessible only. As a result only admin
users could run type-list which is not what we want.

Add a seperate admin only call to provide volume-types with associated

Change-Id: I2a716cd7076fb17fd5f2ceb94363eef0009e9bce

commit_message:
Remove extra-specs from types-list command output

type-list was including the extra-specs info in it's response,
however extra-specs are admin accessible only. As a result only admin
users could run type-list which is not what we want.

Add a seperate admin only call to provide volume-types with associated
extra-specs info (extra-specs-list).

Change-Id: I2a716cd7076fb17fd5f2ceb94363eef0009e9bce

commit_message:
Remove attach/detach code from cinderclient

Attach and Detach actions are done in the novaclient, however
during the creation of Cinder a number of these methods were copied into
the Cinder client.  This is dead code and just adds confusion, so let's
rip it out.

Change-Id: Ib96fe0cac26f19e7d9f2aa01c71ba9762e4f8b8e
Fixes: bug #1071003

DB API call migration_get_by_instance_and_status requires admin
context...and it'll also raise an exception if no migration matches.

_delete() in compute/api was not using admin context, and was checking
for a false return from the DB call vs checking for an exception.

Added a test that covers both problems.

Fixes bug 1056601

Change-Id: Ib3c631dccbb2776761cf5acb8bab1d814bf3e282
(cherry picked from commit 8c9c380935b4aac40269754a291134c130bccec9)
"}]
commit_message:
Fix issues deleting instances in RESIZED state

DB API call migration_get_by_instance_and_status requires admin
context...and it'll also raise an exception if no migration matches.

_delete() in compute/api was not using admin context, and was checking
for a false return from the DB call vs checking for an exception.

Added a test that covers both problems.

Fixes bug 1056601

Change-Id: Ib3c631dccbb2776761cf5acb8bab1d814bf3e282
(cherry picked from commit 8c9c380935b4aac40269754a291134c130bccec9)

[{'created': '2012-10-24 13:23:54.000000000', 'message': 'xenapi: Refactor snapshots during resize

Currently, we use VM.snapshot for resize, which fails if we have a
volume attached to the VM, which does not support snapshots. This change
uses VDI.snapshot instead, for all VDIs that are not attached by nova.

Also needed for xenapi: detaching and reattaching volumes during
migrations and reverting of migrations.

Fixes Bug #1028092

Change-Id: I3e2973747135a9c33de194e38537620c397bb87e
(cherry picked from commit 359527501604ea720b594a2ed1b32cd29fe6adbc)
'}]
commit_message:
xenapi: Refactor snapshots during resize

Currently, we use VM.snapshot for resize, which fails if we have a
volume attached to the VM, which does not support snapshots. This change
uses VDI.snapshot instead, for all VDIs that are not attached by nova.

Also needed for xenapi: detaching and reattaching volumes during
migrations and reverting of migrations.

Fixes Bug #1028092

Change-Id: I3e2973747135a9c33de194e38537620c397bb87e
(cherry picked from commit 359527501604ea720b594a2ed1b32cd29fe6adbc)

This has been here a while now with no +2 support, so I'm back to -1 since I don't really see enough value in it since it's not fixing anything."}, {'account_id': 1297, 'date': '2012-10-15 04:54:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Interesting ideology where only fixing issues, not making code better and more uniform makes it not be accepted, why is that? The later seems like its an issue at least from a conceptual view of issues, but up to u.'}, {'account_id': 1528, 'date': '2012-10-15 12:45:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

My 2c. There doesn't seem to be much improvement in this code. It actually adds one more layer of transformation and more code to check against. It seems like that canonical form for those field names are actually defined by qemu output format than python coding standards.

If it needs to be made cleaner, then maybe an actual QemuImageInfo class with predefined fields rather than string indexes would be a cleaner option. At least that would allow some abstraction in the future if needed (for example to switch implementation to a qemu-img api library if it's ever created)."}, {'account_id': 1904, 'date': '2012-10-17 22:34:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

+1 to Stanislaw Pitucha	comments.
Right now helpers like qemu_img_info() just do simple mapping of command output to dictionary. Subtle change of dictionary keys inside qemu_img_info() can easily cause two types of bugs:
(1) We simple forget to change some lookup by old key somewhere.
(2) Someone doesn't know about the change and assume that qemu_img_info() will return simple dictionary with keys just as they are in qemu-img info command.

This is code-style related change and best way to enforce someone to follow it is to create a class (or namedtuple) QemuImgInfo with properly named fields inside. In case, when it's just a class, error could be detected by tools like pylint right in your favorite text editor or IDE."}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-10-22 17:40:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Interesting to note that this qemu_img_info function appears to be broken with snapshots: https://lists.launchpad.net/openstack/msg17609.html

Whether or not we make the output canonical, we definitely need to add more testing to this method.'}, {'account_id': 1297, 'date': '2012-10-22 17:43:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Durn, multi-line output fail. I can add some better support for that along with this change + tests for that.'}, {'account_id': 1297, 'date': '2012-10-22 22:54:08.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-10-22 23:00:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Appreciate the fix to the existing bug. You should probably add the bug id to the commit message. As to whether it is valuable to do the full conversion into the object, I will leave that to the other reviewers that you were trying to convince ;)'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-10-22 23:19:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Doesn't seem to work

'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2012-10-23 14:15:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

I'll stay safely in Switzerland with a +0.

I think that it makes sense to fix the bug (separately), and that canonicalizing the keys to lowercase with underscores, etc is probably easy to gain support for. I think you should be able to do that without all the RE mess and keep it pretty simple.

However, the random renaming of things (snapshot_list -> snapshots) is likely to cause confusion and I don't really see the value.

Any chance we could see it broken out into patches like:
1. Fix the bug
2. Canonicalize the names
3. Fill in the settings (size, backing file, etc)
4. Your preferred random key renaming scheme

With that, I think folks can +1 (or +2) the pieces they think are reasonable, instead of throwing out the entire thing at once.

Thanks!"}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-10-23 16:36:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Just occurred to me that this patch is a little to big to backport. Is it possible to make it two patches? The first could simply ignore the extra snapshot data, which would fix the bug, then the second could do the refactoring that brings it back an canonicalizes the output. That way we can backport just the first patch to folsom."}, {'account_id': 1297, 'date': '2012-10-23 17:47:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

Sure, 2 is fine. As for RE being a mess, hmmm, not quite so sure I agree there :-P, everyone should be able to figure out basic ones like these.'}, {'account_id': 1297, 'date': '2012-10-23 22:50:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

nits inline... mostly -1'ing because of what appears to be unneeded 'max()'.  I tend to like this re-factor, despite the additional code.

Another minor nit not noted inline:  there's a number of list copies created by slicing while parsing.. I tend to avoid them as you could be more efficient by using list indices where needed, instead.  Not important for parsing a small amount of output, so I'm not asking for this to change... but I tend to be picky about being efficient!"}, {'account_id': 1297, 'date': '2012-10-26 20:04:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

Will do the cleanups. I thought pythons slices wouldn't reallocate (one would think this would be done internally with 'views' on arrays?)"}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-10-26 20:36:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

It's actually considered a feature in some ways; if you want to get a duplicate of a given list, you need merely do:

commit_message:
Move to a more canonicalized output from qemu-img info.

Move to a form that is all lower cased, dashes->underscores, underscores
instead of spaces which allows for better integration with python. Also
make the parser more robust to failures when encountering new fields such
as snapshot lists. Provide a new qemu img info object that can be used
to do the parsing and access the underlying attributes.

Change-Id: Ie098dbd9f06dd4ef966768e2caa128f1d09b019c

commit_message:
libvirt: Fix _cleanup_resize

Undefine domain and unplug vifs in _cleanup_resize if the instance was
migrated to another host.

Fixes bug 1015731

Change-Id: If6eb1ada029d462777bbd6ea113c98c3b801cf5d
(cherry picked from commit d272415fd6fe9cdbd66fdfdf9aedc8a43b87d9b5)

[{'created': '2012-10-31 20:40:03.000000000', 'message': 'Return volume type name on volume create

Update openstack api controller for volumes to fully inflate the
returned volume model on create to populate the volume_type fields so
the response serializer will return the name of the volume_type instead
of the id on volume create requests.  Returning the name on create is
consistent with the show and index commands.

fixes bug #1071436

Change-Id: Ie091cf824a2df40211d8bcfa7f177fc851d737f5
'}]
commit_message:
Return volume type name on volume create

Update openstack api controller for volumes to fully inflate the
returned volume model on create to populate the volume_type fields so
the response serializer will return the name of the volume_type instead
of the id on volume create requests.  Returning the name on create is
consistent with the show and index commands.

fixes bug #1071436

Change-Id: Ie091cf824a2df40211d8bcfa7f177fc851d737f5

commit_message:
Fix nova-network MAC collision logic

The exception being caught and transformed in sqlalchemy/api.py
was incorrect, causing nova-network to miss it in the MAC
collision retry loop.

This patch corrects that and adds a test of the collision logic.

Backports the fix for bug 1059366

Change-Id: I89d17eb8606a18f102e4de0dc76c77205cafbc8d

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-11-01 16:27:15.000000000', 'message': 'Fix auth middleware configuration

Initialze the configuration object before initializing
the middleware, and pass the resulting config in to
the middleware so it can get the configuration settings.

addresses bug #1071047

Change-Id: I2a487d2a2f2d3467e522868ac78dc4645bf7d643
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug.hellmann@dreamhost.com>

commit_message:
Fix auth middleware configuration

Initialze the configuration object before initializing
the middleware, and pass the resulting config in to
the middleware so it can get the configuration settings.

addresses bug #1071047

Change-Id: I2a487d2a2f2d3467e522868ac78dc4645bf7d643
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug.hellmann@dreamhost.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-11-01 16:07:27.000000000', 'message': "support 'send_arp_for_ha' option in l3_agent

Fixes bug 1042046

Sending a gratuitous ARP when a floating IP was added to a gateway
in order to facilitate HA.

I am using iputils-arping package to send ARP packets. You will need
to install iputils-arping on Ubuntu and iputils on Fedora/RHEL/CentOS.

Change-Id: I125dbc57b90027dc5e99ff0a5d6877843a0b02a5
"}, {'created': '2012-11-01 16:07:27.000000000', 'message': "support 'send_arp_for_ha' option in l3_agent

Fixes bug 1042046

Sending a gratuitous ARP when a floating IP was added to a gateway
in order to facilitate HA.

I am using iputils-arping package to send ARP packets. You will need
to install iputils-arping on Ubuntu and iputils on Fedora/RHEL/CentOS.

Change-Id: I125dbc57b90027dc5e99ff0a5d6877843a0b02a5
"}, {'created': '2012-11-01 16:07:27.000000000', 'message': "support 'send_arp_for_ha' option in l3_agent

Fixes bug 1042046

Sending gratuitous ARPs when a external router or a floating
IP was added in order to facilitate HA.

I am using iputils-arping package to send ARP packets. You will need
to install iputils-arping on Ubuntu and iputils on Fedora/RHEL/CentOS.
Arping locates in /usr/bin/arping on Ubuntu and locates in /sbin/arping
on Fedora/RHEL/CentOS.

Change-Id: I125dbc57b90027dc5e99ff0a5d6877843a0b02a5
"}, {'created': '2012-11-01 16:07:27.000000000', 'message': "support 'send_arp_for_ha' option in l3_agent

IP was added in order to facilitate HA.

to install iputils-arping on Ubuntu and iputils on Fedora/RHEL/CentOS.
Arping locates in /usr/bin/arping on Ubuntu and locates in /sbin/arping
on Fedora/RHEL/CentOS.

commit_message:
support 'send_arp_for_ha' option in l3_agent

Fixes bug 1042046

Sending gratuitous ARPs when a external router or a floating
IP was added in order to facilitate HA.

I am using iputils-arping package to send ARP packets. You will need
to install iputils-arping on Ubuntu and iputils on Fedora/RHEL/CentOS.
Arping locates in /usr/bin/arping on Ubuntu and locates in /sbin/arping
on Fedora/RHEL/CentOS.

Change-Id: I125dbc57b90027dc5e99ff0a5d6877843a0b02a5

commit_message:
Make bdms primitive in rpcapi.terminate_instance

This patch converts bdms (a list of block device mappings) passed to
nova.compute.rpcapi.terminate_instance to primitive types that are
safe to be sent to the rpc backend.

Also fixes the fake BDM classes used in:
* nova.tests.api.ec2.test_cloud
* nova.tests.api.openstack.compute.test_server_actions
to pass through josnutils.to_primitive properly and not confuse it due
to wrongly delegated dotted lookups

fixes bug #1073240

Change-Id: I329a48c1a53dde5895a329b39f32854c286de071

- nova/compute/manager.py

commit_message:
Clarify the use of allow_resize_to_same_host Flag

Being referenced in both:

- nova/compute/api.py
- nova/compute/manager.py

This flag is required for both nova-api (that invokes the
resize operation on the scheduler), and nova-compute
(which is invoked by the scheduler with prep_resize)

This makes me wonder if there's a more fundamental problem
with lack of good separation of responsibilities between
the parties involved, and whether the Flag should be needed
only in one place. However this goes beyond the scope of
this documentation effort.

Fix bug 1071931.

Patch also adds a note to the table where this flag is mentioned
so that people can see that it's set to false by default and
that it must be set in both places where nova-compute and
nova-api are run.

Rebase against master.

Change-Id: I731b28f16be80684748c9812256e89faf3897672

according to quantum.conf

Change-Id: I5adf72e6031ad437e05c3521864a83757b3e7887
'}, {'created': '2012-11-01 15:05:42.000000000', 'message': 'Use openstack common log to do logging.

Bug #1073194

We use openstack common log to do logging. At the same time, we will use
quantum logger as our top logger, so that all sub loggers will be set
according to quantum.conf

Change-Id: I5adf72e6031ad437e05c3521864a83757b3e7887
'}, {'created': '2012-11-01 15:05:42.000000000', 'message': 'Use openstack common log to do logging.

We use openstack common log to do logging. At the same time, we will use
quantum logger as our top logger, so that all sub loggers will be set
according to quantum.conf

Change-Id: I5adf72e6031ad437e05c3521864a83757b3e7887
'}, {'created': '2012-11-01 15:05:42.000000000', 'message': 'we remove stdout stream handler if we are using log file to record logs.
Bug #1073194

Before we setup logging, some logger has set up the logging with default
stdout stream handler. So if we want to use only log file to record logs,
we need to remove the default stream handler.

Change-Id: I5adf72e6031ad437e05c3521864a83757b3e7887
'}]
commit_message:
Use openstack common log to do logging.

Bug #1073194

We use openstack common log to do logging. At the same time, we will use
quantum logger as our top logger, so that all sub loggers will be set
according to quantum.conf

Change-Id: I5adf72e6031ad437e05c3521864a83757b3e7887

Build successful

- http://logs.openstack.org/15186/2/check/gate-quantum-merge/2351 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/15186/2/check/gate-quantum-docs/1591 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/15186/2/check/gate-quantum-pep8/2211 : SUCCESS

- http://logs.openstack.org/15186/2/check/gate-quantum-python27/1982 : SUCCESS
'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-11-01 12:46:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Take this line for example:

  greenlet==0.4.0 # greenlet>=0.3.1

It means we use 0.4.0 in the virtualenv we use testing in jenkins etc. but that the developers expect it to work on 0.3.1 or later too'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-11-01 12:46:44.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-11-01 12:46:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I've fixed the script to retain the original ordering

The comments are there as information - we're freezing the versions in pip-requires in order to control the virtualenv we use for testing, but pip-requires has informational value beyond just that use case so I didn't want to destroy that info"}, {'account_id': 1653, 'date': '2012-11-01 12:46:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 1812, 'date': '2012-11-01 12:46:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

As a way to preserve order, and perhaps improve readability and make it more obivous this is an edit, maybe we could
just prepend a # to each existing line, and then
append the new list (without comments) to the end of the file,
with a leading comment indicating that this is the frozen set,
based on the above dependencies...'}, {'account_id': 1812, 'date': '2012-11-01 12:46:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

If it was fairly easy to maintain ordering/comments from the original, I'd do that.

Also it seems that multiple deps are lost from the # orig deps
(see inline comment)"}, {'account_id': 1812, 'date': '2012-11-01 12:46:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 2340, 'date': '2012-11-01 12:46:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I'm not sure about the meaning of the commented-out versions. 

Do they mean all the versions in between are supported? If so, why not allow those versions explicitly, pip will install the latest anyway. 

Do they mean those versions 'might' work? If so, there's not much use for keeping the comments if there's no guarantee."}, {'account_id': 2340, 'date': '2012-11-01 12:46:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

> It means we use 0.4.0 in the virtualenv we use testing in jenkins etc. but that the developers expect it to work on 0.3.1 or later too

Mark: great, so can we also put this note in that comment file header to make it easy to understand for passers-by?'}, {'account_id': 2340, 'date': '2012-11-01 12:46:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: (1 inline comment)

Sorry, I still don't get what information the comments provide exactly. Should this information be kept up-to-date? Will anyone update it if it's in a comment?"}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2012-11-01 12:46:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: No score

(1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2012-11-01 12:46:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

(1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-11-01 12:46:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Abandoned

See http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2012-November/002075.html

It turns out there are setup.py implications I hadn't considered - these versions go in install_requires too

We had actually agreed an approach to solving this at the summit - the nightly stable Jenkins jobs will catch issues like this and we just need to update pip-requires as appropriate when it happens. Jim Blair is going to configure those jobs to send email notifications to the stable-maint team"}]
