'}, {'created': '2012-10-25 05:44:55.000000000', 'message': 'change Quantum network plugin set part

Currently in devstack, we can set Q_PLUGIN value to one of well-known quantum plugins ("openvswitch", "linuxbridge", "ryu").

I would like to run devstack with Q_PLUGIN set to a custom Quantum plugin, but stack.sh exits with an error if I do so.
I feel that this is quite limiting and I would like to offer a patch that allows custom Quantum plugins to be used with devstack.

Please let me know if someone disagrees.

commit_message:
change Quantum network plugin set part

Currently in devstack, Q_PLUGIN can be set to only one of well-known quantum plugins ("openvswitch", "linuxbridge", "ryu").
Setting it to a custom plugin causes stack.sh to exit with an error.
This commit lets you run devstack with Q_PLUGIN set to a custom Quantum plugin.

Change-Id: Iafe07cf162b5b07bee120b0c571149c374004bb3
Signed-off-by: Takaaki Suzuki <suzuki@midokura.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-10-25 12:14:03.000000000', 'message': 'Let scheduler know services' capabilities at startup

Fixes bug 1071254.

Changes:
* Add new rpc-api(fanout) of compute "publish_service_capabilities"
    This rpc-api urges services to send its capabilites to the scheduler.
* Scheduler calls publish_service_capabilities right after the start

By them, the scheduler get to know the capabilities earlier.

Now we can expect that the scheduler always holds the capabilities. So it
is reasonable to change HostManager to ignore hosts whose capabilities are
"None" since it becomes a rare case; this will make scheduling more
reliable. This will achieved by Another patch.

Change-Id: If6582765011fd5e1b794bfdc068e17630ba381cb
'}, {'created': '2012-10-28 00:06:47.000000000', 'message': 'Let scheduler know services' capabilities at startup

Fixes bug 1071254.

Changes:
* Add new rpc-api(fanout) of compute "publish_service_capabilities"
    This rpc-api urges services to send its capabilites to the scheduler.
* Scheduler calls publish_service_capabilities right after the start

By them, the scheduler get to know the capabilities earlier.

Now we can expect that the scheduler always holds the capabilities. So it
is reasonable to change HostManager to ignore hosts whose capabilities are
"None" since it becomes a rare case; this will make scheduling more
reliable. This will achieved by Another patch.

Change-Id: If6582765011fd5e1b794bfdc068e17630ba381cb
'}]
commit_message:
Let scheduler know services' capabilities at startup

Fixes bug 1071254.

Changes:
* Add new rpc-api(fanout) of compute "publish_service_capabilities"
    This rpc-api urges services to send its capabilites to the scheduler.
* Scheduler calls publish_service_capabilities right after the start

By them, the scheduler get to know the capabilities earlier.

Now we can expect that the scheduler always holds the capabilities. So it
is reasonable to change HostManager to ignore hosts whose capabilities are
"None" since it becomes a rare case; this will make scheduling more
reliable. This will achieved by Another patch.

Change-Id: If6582765011fd5e1b794bfdc068e17630ba381cb

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-10-25 00:47:58.000000000', 'message': "Remove double GET on range requests.

The proxy server's ObjectController was performing multiple GET
requests to the object server when processing requests with Range
headers. This was a workaround for a bug in the proxy server's
Controller.GETorHEAD_base method where a response code of 416 from the
object server was incorrectly treated as a bad response from the
backend, the same way a 404 or a 5xx would be.

A 416 (Requested Range Not Satisfiable) from the object server is now
considered a good response. Since the response headers from the object
server already include the X-Object-Manifest header, there's no need
to make a second request (sans Range header) to see if the object is a
manifest.

Bonus fix: updated message for status 416 to match RFC2616.

Bonus fix 2: removed a leftover debugging print() in
test/unit/proxy/test_server.py.

Fixes bug 1065869.

Change-Id: I156af0b463f02ef19a8cfe37092544a599d89b78
"}]
commit_message:
Remove double GET on range requests.

The proxy server's ObjectController was performing multiple GET
requests to the object server when processing requests with Range
headers. This was a workaround for a bug in the proxy server's
Controller.GETorHEAD_base method where a response code of 416 from the
object server was incorrectly treated as a bad response from the
backend, the same way a 404 or a 5xx would be.

A 416 (Requested Range Not Satisfiable) from the object server is now
considered a good response. Since the response headers from the object
server already include the X-Object-Manifest header, there's no need
to make a second request (sans Range header) to see if the object is a
manifest.

Bonus fix: updated message for status 416 to match RFC2616.

Bonus fix 2: removed a leftover debugging print() in
test/unit/proxy/test_server.py.

Fixes bug 1065869.

Change-Id: I156af0b463f02ef19a8cfe37092544a599d89b78

commit_message:
Fix nova-network MAC collision logic

The exception being caught and transformed in sqlalchemy/api.py
was incorrect, causing nova-network to miss it in the MAC
collision retry loop.

This patch corrects that and adds a test of the collision logic.

Fixes bug 1059366

Change-Id: I6bf16c2f59f06c7e84441604b057afd8dfe6d709

commit_message:
removes the nova-volume code from nova

This removes the majority of the nova-volume code from the codebase.
It updates relevent config options to default to cinder. It updates a
number of existing tests that were depending on code that was removed.

A few things still need to be removed:

 * volume/driver.py & volume/iscsi.py
   These files are used by the libvirt volume driver tests. These
   tests should be updated to mock the relevant calls.

 * scheduler/simple.py & scheduler/multi.py
   These files should no longer be necessary so they can be removed
   in a subsequent patch

 * exception.py cleanup
   Once the above files are removed there are a number of unused
   exceptions which can be removed

 * database calls and database tables
   The database calls have not been removed and the tables have not
   been dropped. This can be done in a separate migration

 * additional config options and nova.conf.sample
   There may be a few extra config options that can be removed and the
   conf sample can be regenerated

Implements bp delete-nova-volume

Change-Id: I0b540e54dbabd26901a7530035a38583bb521fda

commit_message:
Don't elevate context when calling run_instance

The filter scheduler should be passing a regular context to compute
when calling run_instance instead of an elevated context.

Fixes bug 1072205

Change-Id: I4d4f96e17eef8050c25b63f4b26d7d376a91cb80

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-10-28 23:03:45.000000000', 'message': 'l3_nat_agent was renamed to l3_agent
and this was missed.

This broke quantum-l3-agent when setup.py was
used to install but  did not affect package installs.

This change fixes the issue.

Change-Id: I820d26fba5d2774262577ed4fbae81dc7362e93e
'}]
commit_message:
l3_nat_agent was renamed to l3_agent
and this was missed.

This broke quantum-l3-agent when setup.py was
used to install but  did not affect package installs.

This change fixes the issue.

Change-Id: I820d26fba5d2774262577ed4fbae81dc7362e93e

commit_message:
Call iptables without absolute path.

Fixes bug 1069966

rootwrap expects the command name is not absolute. We need to call
the command without path to make rootwrap work well.

Change-Id: I6120103908d10ca257d177a320294de06a89c646

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-10-28 22:34:29.000000000', 'message': 'Ensures port is not created when database exception occurs

Fixes bug 1064261

The port creation code did not correctly treat a database error. That is,
if there was an exception the port would be created and an error returned
to the client.

Change-Id: I6cf36d1c641b46716afb16f228b8daa631099a5d
'}]
commit_message:
Ensures port is not created when database exception occurs

Fixes bug 1064261

The port creation code did not correctly treat a database error. That is,
if there was an exception the port would be created and an error returned
to the client.

Change-Id: I6cf36d1c641b46716afb16f228b8daa631099a5d

commit_message:
Update policies

Merge in update openstack-common policy code.

Updates Quantum-specific policy glue code to eliminate deprecated
openstack-common policy interfaces.  Also cleans up policy code
to allow for returning fine-grained policy values.

Change-Id: I2951a0de3751bd2ec868e7a661070fed624e4af2

Interesting: I went with a completely different approach. See the following changes:
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/13944/
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/14027/
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/14028/
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/14029/

I think the first change would be relevant for your approach -- maybe you could rebase your changes on top of this patch?

The other patches are an alternative to adding rpms-suse files, like you did; I believe simply adding a new list of packages won't scale well for maintenance of devstack."}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-10-16 06:03:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Abandoned

2. new rpm package requires list for suse
3. bug fix or workaround

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-10-25 21:32:56.000000000', 'message': "Rehydrate NetworkInfo in reboot_instance()

In the process of implementing no-db-compute, the compute manager's
reboot_instance() was stripped of its database accesses for getting
an instance's block and network device info. That information is
now passed in from the API layer over RPC.

In the offending changeset (), the network_info was getting coerced
to a list and thus calls to NetworkInfo.legacy() were failing in the
manager's _legacy_nw_info() method. This patch rehydrates the
NetworkInfo using the existing method for doing so, which fixes
bug 1071017. A test is also added to prevent future regressions.

Change-Id: I8fd1c2dde573bb7da3bfe1ee3193f9ba1167aaa7
"}, {'created': '2012-10-25 22:55:25.000000000', 'message': "Rehydrate NetworkInfo in reboot_instance()

In the process of implementing no-db-compute, the compute manager's
reboot_instance() was stripped of its database accesses for getting
an instance's block and network device info. That information is
now passed in from the API layer over RPC.

In the offending changeset (), the network_info was getting coerced
to a list and thus calls to NetworkInfo.legacy() were failing in the
manager's _legacy_nw_info() method. This patch rehydrates the
NetworkInfo using the existing method for doing so, which fixes
bug 1071017. A test is also added to prevent future regressions.

Change-Id: I8fd1c2dde573bb7da3bfe1ee3193f9ba1167aaa7
"}]
commit_message:
Rehydrate NetworkInfo in reboot_instance()

In the process of implementing no-db-compute, the compute manager's
reboot_instance() was stripped of its database accesses for getting
an instance's block and network device info. That information is
now passed in from the API layer over RPC.

In the offending changeset (), the network_info was getting coerced
to a list and thus calls to NetworkInfo.legacy() were failing in the
manager's _legacy_nw_info() method. This patch rehydrates the
NetworkInfo using the existing method for doing so, which fixes
bug 1071017. A test is also added to prevent future regressions.

Change-Id: I8fd1c2dde573bb7da3bfe1ee3193f9ba1167aaa7

It seems to obey the --config-file option for me.  No other bin/* files have this change you're adding...  Can you explain further?  (Maybe I'm not understanding the problem)"}, {'account_id': 5441, 'date': '2012-10-26 13:12:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

nova-dhcpbridge does obey the config-file directive, but the issue is that nova-dhcpbridge is passed to dnsmasq in restart_dhcp() in nova/network/linux_net.py.  There's support for overriding the FLAGFILE env variable in that call, but it would require a larger code change to pass a --config-file argument to nova-dhcpbridge in that call.

The TL;DR of the issue is that if I start nova-network with an alternate config I have no way to get nova-dhcpbridge to use that same config when restart_dhcp() is called, this fixes that."}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2012-10-26 13:24:58.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Code seems fine ... can you add the additional explanation from your last comment to the commit message?  I think it's useful for the record."}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2012-10-26 13:31:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

[{'created': '2012-10-26 03:32:50.000000000', 'message': "Fix config-file overrides for nova-dhcpbridge

nova-dhcpbridge can read in an alternate config file location but wasn't
using it to parse config options.  This hooks it back up.

Change-Id: I002ea768500555a089bd1d5b0fea2354b27fba14
"}, {'created': '2012-10-26 14:06:54.000000000', 'message': "Fix config-file overrides for nova-dhcpbridge

nova-dhcpbridge can read in an alternate config file location but wasn't
using it to parse config options.  This fixes a regression introduced in
00786bc554a2dfacb3c6f02fbb7e9c98f35d4262.

This change is motivated by the fact that nova-dhcpbridge is passed to
dnsmasq in restart_dhcp() in nova/network/linux_net.py, and there is
currently no support for overriding config options for nova-dhcpbridge
in that call.  There is support for overriding the FLAGFILE env variable
in that call, but nova-dhcpbridge was ignoring that.  If I start
nova-network with an alternate config this provides a way for me to pass
that config to nova-dhcpbridge as well.

Change-Id: I002ea768500555a089bd1d5b0fea2354b27fba14
"}]
commit_message:
Fix config-file overrides for nova-dhcpbridge

nova-dhcpbridge can read in an alternate config file location but wasn't
using it to parse config options.  This fixes a regression introduced in
00786bc554a2dfacb3c6f02fbb7e9c98f35d4262.

This change is motivated by the fact that nova-dhcpbridge is passed to
dnsmasq in restart_dhcp() in nova/network/linux_net.py, and there is
currently no support for overriding config options for nova-dhcpbridge
in that call.  There is support for overriding the FLAGFILE env variable
in that call, but nova-dhcpbridge was ignoring that.  If I start
nova-network with an alternate config this provides a way for me to pass
that config to nova-dhcpbridge as well.

Change-Id: I002ea768500555a089bd1d5b0fea2354b27fba14

commit_message:
Change hacking.py N306 to use logical_lines

Only logical lines (does not include comments) should be checked for
alphabetical import order.  This patch changes N306
(imports not in alphabetical order) to run on logical lines not physical lines.

Fixes bug 1071849

Change-Id: Ib2cb92f9eb82aeed1ff5879d3e38c8961b4f06cc

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-10-26 05:38:04.000000000', 'message': "Fix use of elevated context for resize methods

elevated contexts were being passed over RPC to confirm_resize and
revert_resize methods.  If those methods need to elevate context, they
should do so themselves.

There was 1 case (when deleting an instance in RESIZED) when we'd send a
non-elevated context to confirm_resize().  This would fail because the
migration_get() call there requires admin context and confirm_resize()
on the manager side did not elevate the context itself.

This fixes bug 1071600 and removes sending elevated contexts for these
methods over RPC.

(Ultimately we need some work to make the migration* DB API calls verify
project_id vs requiring admin context..)

Change-Id: I907889502f19fba8059253e52dca084a123016e2

commit_message:
Fix use of elevated context for resize methods

elevated contexts were being passed over RPC to confirm_resize,
revert_resize, and finish_revert_resize methods.  If those methods need
to elevate context, they should do so themselves.

There was 1 case (when deleting an instance in RESIZED) when we'd send a
non-elevated context to confirm_resize().  This would fail because the
migration_get() call there requires admin context and confirm_resize()
on the manager side did not elevate the context itself.

This fixes bug 1071600 and removes sending elevated contexts for these
methods over RPC.

(Ultimately we need some work to make the migration* DB API calls verify
project_id vs requiring admin context..)

subject: Add and use Debian->Fedora package map
messages:
[{'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-10-04 14:23:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Works for me

Build successful

- http://logs.openstack.org/14028/1/check/gate-devstack-merge/1276 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/14028/1/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm/13622 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/14028/1/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-cinder/3601 : SUCCESS
'}, {'account_id': 5727, 'date': '2012-10-09 16:42:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

here is my concerns about this solution:
1. as a platform independent installation script, stack.sh is heavily depending on package schema of debian, as a platform dependent programmer, we have to understand the differences and relations of packages on two platform(debian & suse or others). And packages on different platform might be quite hard to map each other. I do expect that, installation should run smoothly on all platforms, but it's supporting programmer should only focus on merely one platform.
2. there are circumstances, vendors have their different favorite packages over others, so maturity of packages on a platform would make us have to chose a specific package on certain platform, where, as a high level cloud solution, openstack would definitely not prohibit, so finally we have to make a package installed and run on another platform(say debian) before we make it ready on our platform(say suse).

thank you for your good idea."}, {'account_id': 4460, 'date': '2012-10-09 18:11:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Laurence: I'm not sure I understand your comment. Do you have a concrete example where things would not be working with this approach?"}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2012-10-20 00:57:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I also find this approach confusing, I'd much rather have explicit lists per distro. Devstack is also often used by people to study what's needed for OpenStack, so having to sneak in fedora dependencies into a debian list, so it can be mapped back to a fedora list is really confusing. Just split up rpms into rpms-rh rpms-suse or something instead."}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-10-27 06:03:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-10-27 06:03:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2012-10-04 14:04:25.000000000', 'message': "Add and use Debian->Fedora package map

We also add symlinks to use this package map for Red Hat and CentOS.

Note that it means that dist fields in files/apts/ are also used for
Fedora too now. There's even an instance where it's used to install a
package exclusively on Fedora (xinetd, for swift).

Change-Id: I030be3a36d4d13fa4061e74231f552096839d702
"}]
commit_message:
Add and use Debian->Fedora package map

We also add symlinks to use this package map for Red Hat and CentOS.

Note that it means that dist fields in files/apts/ are also used for
Fedora too now. There's even an instance where it's used to install a
package exclusively on Fedora (xinetd, for swift).

Change-Id: I030be3a36d4d13fa4061e74231f552096839d702

commit_message:
Fix check for memory_mb

assert_compute_node_has_enough_memory should check memory_mb is None or not

_assert_dest_node_has_enough_disk should check available_mb as well

Fixes bug 884842

Change-Id: Ieaa33efd50bb84f1b475c437b26af1302fdfd19f

'}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2012-10-27 01:18:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: (3 inline comments)

Thanks for cleanups.

In the current implementation check for ethertype and protocol depends on a plugin implementation. By using the following way, SecuityGroupDbMixin can check if ethertype/protocol is valid and an individual plugin can change supported protocols. After this, each plugin does not need to implement the validation logic for ethertype/protocol. How about it?

----
class SecuityGroupDbMixin(...):
   sg_supported_protocols = ['tcp', 'udp', 'icmp']
   sg_supported_ethertypes = ['IPv4', 'IPv6']

   def check_xxxx(self):
       # validation logic here
----

In each plugin implementation (like NVP plugin),
they can be changed to any value:

----
class NvpPluginV2(db_base_plugin_v2.QuantumDbPluginV2,
                  securitygroups_db.SecuityGroupDbMixin):

   def __init__(self):
       ....
       self.sg_supported_ethertypes = ['IPv4', 'IPv6', 'GRE']
----

Some minor cleanups are found in inline comments."}, {'account_id': 2035, 'date': '2012-10-27 01:18:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

This patch set fixes the transaction issue I had in patch set 9. Special thanks to  markmcclain for helping me solve that. 

In addition adds a flag proxy_mode mode which when enabled enforces external_id to be passed and the context.is_admin has to be True. The reason for this is because nova uses an auto incremented id so we dont' want a tenant to be able to pass in an external_id. n-api can make this call as the quantum admin user since those credentials are required in the nova.conf for quantum."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-10-27 01:18:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12: Works for me

commit_message:
Quantum Security Groups API

Implements blueprint quantum-security-groups API

In addition the the convention that if a URI has a '-' in it, it's
replaced with a '_'. For example: POST security-groups will convert
the body to {'security_group':  ..}

Change-Id: I2c5219ed1d44a43ce1bf03d49df9f5c1af23352b

commit_message:
heat engine : add heat_waitcondition_server_url

Add config option for waitcondition server, since metadata
and waitcondition notifications are no longer handled by the
same API

Change-Id: Idc1b39c6c60b8473316fe4861f0f060568540b09
Signed-off-by: Steven Hardy <shardy@redhat.com>
